Metadata: Observation of seiche forcing and amplification in three small harbors
"Journal of Waterway, Port, Coastal, and Ocean Engineering," 122(5):232-238, September/Octob​er 1996.

Extensive field observations are used to characterize seiches in three small harbors with similar surface areas, water depths, and swell wave climates. On the continental shelf just offshore of each harbor mouth, the energy levels of waves in the infragravity frequency band vary by more than a factor of 200 in response to comparably large variations in swell energy levels. Energy levels in this swell-driven frequency band also vary (less dramatically) in response to changes in the swell frequency and with tidal stage. Motions at longer seiche periods are primarily driven by meteorological and other processes (a tsunami-​generated seiche is described). As has often been observed, the amplification of seiche energy with each harbor basin varies as a function of seiche frequency, and is largest at the frequency of the lowest resonant harbor mode. At all three harbors, the average amplification of the grave mode decreases with increasing seiche energy, a trend consistent with a nonlinear dissipation mechanism such as flow separation in the harbor mouth or sidewall and bottom friction.
